1.title: Artificial Intelligence
1.subtitle: Technology simulating and enhancing human cognitive capabilities
1.content: Artificial intelligence (AI) is a term used to describe a suite of related technologies intended to simulate and enhance human cognitive capabilities, such as pattern recognition, judgment, vision, or hearing. 2.subtitle: Stimulating peoples' desire to make good choices by understanding their motivators
2.content: Most people want to make healthier life decisions, be financially responsible and contribute to a sustainable society and environment. 3.subtitle: Large and complex data sets increasingly available for algorithmic analysis
3.content: Big data generally refers to datasets so large and complex they create significant challenges for traditional data management and analysis tools in practical timeframes. 5.title: Citizen Science
5.subtitle: Data collection or analysis projects done by volunteers to aid research
5.content: Citizen science is a research technique that utilizes local citizens as resources to gather information for scientists in a large research project. 6.subtitle: Getting needed services, ideas or content from a large group
6.content: Crowdsourcing is the practice of obtaining needed services, ideas, content or data by soliciting contributions from a large group of people, typically via an online platform, rather than from traditional employees or suppliers (Merriam-Webster). 7.subtitle: Consider structured and unstructured data from many sources to gain insights
7.content: Big Data is a term used to describe the collection, storing and processing of huge volumes of data. 8.title: Design Thinking
8.subtitle: Principles and practices focused on developing products/service/experiences focused on needs of users.
8.content: Design thinking is a set of principles, practices and processes that are used in developing products, experiences and services based on the needs of the user. 9.title: Experimentation
9.subtitle: Rigorous testing of ideas or approaches to measure cause-and-effect of variables
9.content: Experimentation entails using a rigorous method to test an idea or an approach to help identify what does and doesn’t work. 10.title: Foresight
10.subtitle: Systematically imagine plausible futures based on data and trends.
10.content: Foresight is a process of anticipating and managing change. Foresight methods are used for strategic policy and planning to systematically imagine plausible futures based on current data, trends and policies. The most common foresight approach is scenario planning. Scenarios are credible, challenging stories

11.title: Gamification
11.subtitle: Applying game elements to trigger challenge mindsets and desired behaviours
11.content: Gamification is the use of game elements and game design techniques in non-game contexts. 11.author: Amelie Veillette, Peter Massie

12.title: Hackathon/Appathon
12.subtitle: A time limited event where teams build solutions on a predetermined theme.
12.content: A hackathon is an intense (usually 24-72 hours long) and creative event during which participants are put into teams that build solutions related to a predetermined theme. Traditionally hackathons (and their cousins Appathons, Codefests, and Pitch Camps) result in new apps, software programs, or prog
12.author: Jason Pearman

13.title: Innovation Hubs/Labs
13.subtitle: Teams focused on applying techniques to reframe problems, generate solutions or grow innovation capacity
13.content: Innovation Hubs/Labs (also known as innovation teams, labs, units) are differentiated from other teams in that they often adopt new and experimental methods to tackle various social and public issues. 14.subtitle: Teams focused on applying techniques to reframe problems, generate solutions or grow innovation capacity
14.content: Open data is data that is structured and machine-readable, freely shared, used and built on without restrictions (open.canada.ca). 15.title: Open Policy Making
15.subtitle: Creating government policy with direct contributions from external parties
15.content: Open Policy Making refers broadly to the process of creating government policy with direct contributions from the public and other external parties. 16.title: Pay for Performance
16.subtitle: Financial rewards for achieving outcome targets
16.content: Pay-for-performance (PFP) refers to funding arrangements where a commissioning organization financially rewards service delivery organizations (or private investors in the case of a social impact bond) for achieving agreed upon outcome targets. PFP is sometimes referred to as Pay-for-Success (PFS)

17.subtitle: Competitions to invite participation in solving particular problems.
17.content: Prize challenges are a form of crowdsourcing that use competitions with prizes (e.g. monetary, recognition, access, etc.) to incent broad or targeted participation in helping to solve particular problems. 18.content: The 'public service mutual' (PSM) or mutual is shorthand for a variety of initiatives, based on mutual or cooperative governance that in whole or in part delivers public services and in which employee or member control plays a significant role in their operation. 20.content: Smart Regulation aims to achieve public confidence in regulatory effectiveness while limiting the burden on those being regulated. 21.subtitle: Preventative and integrated solutions to better address complex social challenges
21.content: There are many definitions for “social innovation”, which all broadly refer to new solutions that better address complex social challenges, such as youth homelessness, long-term unemployment, or the social isolation of seniors. 22.subtitle: Outcomes measures for articulating the impact of programming
22.content: Social metrics are the measurement and articulation of social outcomes.
